Pipe-weed (also known as Halflings Leaf or simply Leaf) was a plant developed by the Hobbits of the Shire.
==History==
Apparently the plant grew in Númenor and was brought to Middle-earth by Númenóreans during the Second Age. In Gondor it grew as a wild herb
column2: appreciated primarily for its fragrant blossoms and the Gondorians knew it as sweet galenas or more popularly as westmansweed

column1: It was not until the Third Age when it reached Eriador
column3: and the Bree-hobbits were the first to use it for smoking. From Bree the habit of smoking pipe-weed spread to other regions
column4: as well as to other races

column1: But it was in the Shire where it was first domesticated
column2: by Tobold Hornblower of Longbottom in Southfarthing around . The cultivation and exportation of this herb became a key industry in the Shire
column3: especially in the south. Popular varieties of pipe-weed included Longbottom Leaf
column5: and Southern Star from the Shire. Perhaps less popular was Southlinch from Bree.

column1: The Wizards Gandalf learned to smoke pipe-weed from the Hobbits and was often seen blowing smoke-rings. Saruman initially derided him for this
column2: but at some point he took up smoking himself
column3: and even had commerce with the Shire: After the destruction of Isengard
column4: pipe-weed was found among its stores
column5: but the Hobbits Meriadoc Brandybuck and Peregrin Took failed to realize the Sharkey.

column1: After the War of the Ring
column2: Meriadoc Brandybuck authored Herblore of the Shire discussing the origins and history of the Hobbits art of smoking Pipe-weed.

column1: ==Inspiration==
In the prologue to The Lord of the Rings
column2: Tolkien stated specifically that "it is a strain of the herb nicotiana"
column3: i.e. tobacco. Whether the substance is psychoactive remains unclear.

column1: ==Etymology==
The common Gondorian name of pipe-weed was Westmansweed. The more noble name was galenas (a Gondor Sindarin form of the proper Sindarin form galanes)
column2: with Quenya forms alanesse or alenesse derived from GALA "plant
